item.description: When identifying episode boundaries: Per Nikitina, the distribution of forms is sensitive to +-Start of unit. The forms populating the distribution are language-specific What is stable across languages is: (1) which form types are sensitive, (2) the fact that there's a binary contrasts between start and non-start, (3) the rough distribution (1) Form types Word frequency Adverb types Verbs (Word frequency overall) Other Referring expressions Backgrounding Tense/aspect (2) Start vs non-start //What about end signaling? Is there any? That's a question for next readings.//(3) Rough distribution NB My understanding of stats & distribution is naive, but this is what I understood. Distribution is similar overall whatever the forms concerned. Eg similar distribution of Wan past-perfect and Chuvash past-perfect. OTOH, in some cases, it is not, & then it must be explained in terms of grammatical difference. Eg pro-drop lg VS non-prop-drop lg = noun VS pronouns do not have comparable distribution across languages. //There's more to say about 'Expected vs exceptional distribution -> impact on theory'. item.title: MAIN_Notes
item.description:
Sources: Gagarina et al 2012. MAIN: Multilingual Assessment Instrument for Narratives Gagarina Bohnacker 2019. MAIN: Multilingual Assessment Instrument for Narratives -- Revised Gagarina, Bohnacker & Lindgren 2019. Macrostructural organization of adults' oral narrative texts (MAIN team at ZAS. CLAN transcription rules for MAIN) Gagarina et al 2012 _ MAIN (presentation of the method & design behind it = unrevised version) / Background, models and terms, source mining Gagarina & Bohnacker 2019 introduces the revised model; Revised materials & transcription procedure are available on the project's website
https://www.leibniz-zas.de/de/publications/schriftenreihe/zaspil/zaspil-63/main-63-download#c2844 Benchmark:
Gagarina et al 2019 - German, Russian, Swedish; adults / Monolingual research, background, cultural variation, theory  Metastudy: Lindgren et al 2019 _ MAIN (review of studies on multilingual children) / Multilingual research Compare with ENNI; same purpose but developed for monolingual populations.Multilingual Assesment Instrument for Narratives (MAIN) is a set of methods and tools designed to study children's (age 3-10) narrative skills in one or more languages. MAIN seems like the most popular framework for narrative research involving macrostructure in recent years. There's a large body of research available: monolingual, multilingual, adult benchmarks,... The range of languages/cultures covered is significant but still heavily skews towards Europe. There's also been a real effort to make the macrostructure model relevant to a large range of languages/cultures. Study with MAIN conducted in Africa seems limited to Afrikaans-English + Afrikaans-Xhosa (South Africa). ...Diagnostic evaluation (speech language pathology) Language acquisition, cross-linguistic comparisonIts main purpose is to screen for language impairments among bilingual children, and monolingual children, with the same protocol.Storyboard elicitation. Set of four stories presented through a sequence of 6 pictures. These stories were designed directly for MAIN. They are controlled for complexity, and cross-cultural appropriateness.Data collected from children & adults (adults serve as benchmarks for children) Multiple languages/cultures; monolingual and multilingualTerms and def. taken from Gagarina et al 2019 (revised model) I may find more later, there's scattering in between initial & revised model (3 publications or more)
Transcription rules are very explicit & precise (see MAIN_Transcription_rules), probably informed by conversation analysis. Annotation procedure much less so. Description of annotation is given in:
Gagarina et al 2012_MAIN p.13: Westby's decision tree shown as guide to code episodes. Gagarina et al 2019_MAIN_Adult p.197-198: This article lists the categories, without describing the process. Multiple coders with high agreement. Lindgren Bohnacker 2022 p.492: This article lists the coding categories, without describing the process. Klopp & Smith 2025 p.181-182: Coding of macrostructure relies on Westby's decision tree. Data labelled as "no sequence" receive an additional label: description, or action. Two coders, with high agreement. No description of process beyond that.
Started looking for an annotated dataset on MAIN's website. Could continue: https://zenodo.org/records/4724970#.Yf1qqKbMK5d They have a standard annotation procedure that produces high agreement between codes. It's practical for their purpose, but flawed theory-wise. Checked other sources to see if I could find a more recent & comprehensive annotation procedure; I did not find anything of the sort. Gagarina & Bohnacker 2019_MAIN-revised Lindgren et al 2019
Full package of MAIN documents on website; Transcription Rules does not touch on annotation. See https://www.leibniz-zas.de/de/publications/schriftenreihe/zaspil/zaspil-63/main-63-download#c2844 Old notesExamples of score rubric shown in Gagarina et al 2012: 67-86 One score rubric created per story The score rubric has more or less items depending on the complexity & length of the story.Here's a rough adaptation:The rubric also tracks: Quantified version of "Structural complexity" Nb of AO sequences Nb of G (no AO) sequences Nb of GA / GO sequence Nb of GAO sequences Nb of internal state terms (total and nb by type) When adapting this protocol for labelling data, quantification of structural complexity can flow directly from coding data with macrostructure categories. Partial list: Lindgren & Bohnacker 2022 _ German, Swedish / Multilingual research  Tribushinina, Irmawati & Mak 2022 _ Indonesian, Dutch / Multilingual research  Bohnacker, Lindgren & Öztekin 2022 _ Turkish, Swedish / Multilingual research  Fiani, Henry & Prévost 2022 _ Lebanese Arabic, French / Multilingual research   Fichman & al 2022 _ Russian, Hebrew / Multilingual research  Kosutar et al 2022 _ Croatian / Monolingual research  Lindgren 2019 _ Swedish / Monolingual research  Klop & Smith 2025 _ Afrikaans, Xhosa See also:
https://main.leibniz-zas.de/en/research/publications/
https://main.leibniz-zas.de/en/research/projects/ Their narrative model was designed for cross-cultural applicability, and revised based on observed differences. It's precise & suitable for comparative research. The main weakness is that it's built around a very specific method/purpose (storyboard elicitation + diagnostic evaluation of children), which creates cultural bias, even despite the explicit effort to increase cross-cultural applicability, because SLP diagnosis only takes place in a subset of societies (must be Rich/Industrialized)....

item.title: LabovWaletzky1967_Notes
item.description:
Source: Labov & Waletzky 1967. Narrative analysis: Oral versions of personal experienceRussian formalist narratology: Propp (p.13)Labov & Waletzky (1967) developed a model to study narratives; specifically oral narrative by average speakers. It is the most influential linguistic approach to date (perhaps with more influence in social sciences than linguistics per se). They innovated by studying oral versions of personal experiences narrated by average speakers, whereas previous research studied folk tales, myths, legends... narrated by expert storytellers. doing-narrative-research2023_labov / Background, models and terms  berman1997_labov  johnstone2016_labov  Context: Prior research modeled narratives with a narrow, idealized dataset (myths, folk stories,... by expert storytellers). Better modeling can be achieved with a wider dataset (wider range of narratives, and of storytellers represented). (p.12) Implicit connection with lang acq (age variation) and variationist description (class, origin, race,... variation) This work models tellings of personal experiences by average speakers from diverse backgrounds. It enriches narrative research by considering new types of narratives, and a different set of storytellers. (p.12) Purpose: Theory building NB NOT STORYBOARD-BASED Interviewer prompts a speaker to narrate a personal experience involving danger/risk of death Data collected in two settings (with other community members, or without) From a diverse set of speakers (variable age -- adults only --, race, and place of origin = +-urban). Single language/cultureThis is a reconstruction; the description of the coding schema is scattered and incomplete.Transcription is divided into clauses.  All clauses are labelled. A subset of verbs are labelled (+), which results in labelling all verbs (+/-).Publications; purpose + participant demographicsSome engagement with Labov in these articles:  Nicolas  Ntuli 2025 -- uses L&W categories for its coding  Rungrojsuwan 2019  
Shunhua-Tianlong2023   Could find more research of this type Converges how, relative to source?(TBC) Terms, definitions, coding schemas (partial) Purpose (lang acq, variationist description)Diverges how, relative to source?(TBC) Method Terms, definitions and coding schemas (partial) Purpose (? discourse studies ?) Limits of L&W: Few macrostructure categories + fit poorly with other methods (<-> other types of narratives) + ?method not widely adopted? (ethical problem + not suitable for some populations) Story grammar eg Stein & Glenn improves on macrostructure granularity, accuracy, & fit with multiple types of narrative <-> methods Early example of work that analyzes how micro- & macrostructure interface Innovation in method to capture variationist data Collecting data with more than one setting condition is valuable + has not been reproduced much

item.title: Ji2002_Notes
item.description: p.1257: Episode transitions are defined by major changes in time, space, and/or theme. When the content of a narrative lack such changes (absent, or change is not major), the episode boundary is less clear.p.1259-1960. This study builds on: Chafe (1979, 1980 = Pear story data), re types of discontinuity Prideaux & Hogan (1993) + Givon (1993), re marked sentence structures p.1262: Discontinuity tends to be introduced by marked structures. The study was conducted in English, so marked structure = sentence with any of these sentence-initially: AdvP PrepP ParticipP NounP SubordinateP Types of discontinuities labelled & quantified (p.1262-1263): Temporal discontinuity Spatial discontinuity Thematic discontinuity (new theme or participant*. + NO explicit link with previous elements. //No data of this type in any group, see p. 1262 + 1266.//) Thematic reorientation (type of thematic discontinuity = new theme or participant. + THERE IS explicit link with previous elements) (Thematic discontinuity vs reorientation = p.1265) * Participant means character in story. Author divided data in three groups representing rates of agreement; Group 1: >70% (p.1261) Group 2: 40-69% (p.1265) Group 3: 1-39% (p.1265)(p.1261-1265) There is a high rate (> 70%) of agreement between research subjects, re: episode boundaries, when: there is a major change in time, place and/or theme, AND when there is a marked structure. Regarding theme, agreement stays high when: new theme is a participant (p.1264); or there is an anaphor (callback to previous element; what they define as "thematic reorientation") (p.1265). //Looking further: Anaphora in group 1 all introduce "larger unit" or new participant + have a marked structure.// (p.1266-1269) Rate of agreement re episode boundaries drops in these conditions. (p.1266-1267) When there are less marked sentence structures (group 1 had 80% whereas group 2 had 41% and group 3 had 50%); When thematic reorientation has either of these properties: (p.1267) When new NON-PARTICIPANT theme is introduced, regardless of whether the sentence structure is marked. (Seen in group 2 & 3.) (p.1268) When new theme introduction starts a small unit (group 3), agreement drop is larger than when it "initiates a larger unit" (group 2). //No further explanation included; examples supporting the statement are on p.1267+1268. I think this is about shifting between episodes 'on same level' vs shifting between those 'on different levels'.// (p.1268) When the discontinuity (of any type; time-space-theme) is not major. (Author calls these "local".) So, according to this study, the variables that make episode boundaries more or less salient are: +- Marked sentence +- Discontinuity in time, space +- Discontinuity in theme, only with additional features: +- New participant +- Anaphor (so non-participant theme with no callback = adds very little episode boundary salience, for example. NB Why not split Theme further & more precisely? + Anaphor is meaningful for the structure beyond this, at minimum in terms of NP vs Pron, what else?) +- Major discontinuity (any type) //There's a lot to unpack re discontinuity of theme First: what's happening would be clearer with precise, labelled splitting of theme. The problem is how you do you split it, and how do you justify your split? I can think of: participant VS internal state VS dialogue VS packaged action/event. Second: Anaphor is meaningful outside thematic discontinuity. Most obviously regarding NP/pronouns to refer to participants. Also in some cases of discontinuity in time or place (less sure about that). The problem is that switch between anaphor & non-anaphor has multiple triggers (eg memory decay), and anaphor can be distant or local. Switches are a cue for ep boundary, yet there are switches within episodes, and non-switches across episodes. ... (Rest of reflection in Ep boundaries_Thinking out loud.) //(p.1269) "The episode seems to be perceived by language users mainly as a unit of events or actions" //-- This explains why new non-participant theme & non-major discontinuity can get perceived as indicating episode shift and not indicating episode shift; because they don't impose a new "event-action unit", essentially.//Source/claim miningp.1258: "It has also been established that narrative is not composed merely of sequences of sentences, but is hierarchically organized into intermediate units such as episodes or paragraphs (Bamberg and Marchman, 1991; Black and Bower, 1979; van Dijk, 1982; Grimes, 1975; Hinds, 1977, 1979; Longacre, 1979; Pu, Prideaux, and Stanford, 1992; Tomlin, 1987."p.1259: "Empirical support for the validity of episodes has been provided by psycholinguistic studies which indicate that people recalling stories treat information of an episode as an integral unit (cf. Black and Bower, 1979; Glenn, 1978; Mandler, 1978; Thorndyke, 1977), a result which is further supported by studies that have found the episode-shift effect, i.e., readers pause longer in processing episode-initial sentences that introduce an episode shift than they do for episode-internal sentences (Haberlandt, Berian, and Sandson, 1980; Mandler and Goodman, 1982)"p.1264: "Many researchers have proposed that the default assumption of readers is that the order in which the events are reported corresponds to the chronological order of these events (e.g., Comrie, 1985; Dowty, 1986; Fleischman, 1990; Givon, 1992; Hopper, 1979). This has been called the iconicity assumption (Fleischman, 1990; Hopper, 1979)."

item.title: TrabassoNickels1992_Ep boundaries
item.description:
Episode as a working memory during production: p.272-273p.260 Extracting Episodic Structures Example of "complete" episode: event, goal, attempt, outcome, reaction Example of a "well-formed" episode: two events, goal, attempt, successful outcome -- all with causal relation Example of "basic" episodes: goal, attempt, outcome p.264-265 Episodic Structures Two types of unit: episode (contains GAO), and non-GAO unit (not an episode; "consists of a clause or a set of clauses that maintain a topic but does not allow the inference of a goal") I assume they proceeded more or less like this: Look at each clause; attribute "function of clause", and "level". (I assume these must be coding tiers.) Eg first clause is "event", "level 1". (1) Review all functions: Spot local GAO sequences = these are episodes. Sort categories other than GAO (event, setting, IRC = internal state) into the identified episodes. In my example, clauses given the function G3-A-O form an episode, all at level 3. (2) Review again. Look for distant GAO sequences (with intervening level change) = these are also episodes. An episode must be able to count as a narrative unit within another episode; otherwise there would be no larger episodes, they would always have a unit missing. This could be solved with an extra tier "function of episode". Whatever remains belongs to no episodes = counts as non-GAO unit.
There are no appendices or examples of annotated data in text.Figures, for context.(1a) Their causal network captures how narrative categories can connect. (1b) It captures how episodes connect through goal hierarchy. (4) See how a network based on frog story data is similar to their 1b figure.

item.title: Overview_Nov2025
item.description:
I think that an analysis of narrative structure grounded in recent theory ideally integrates some, or ideally all of these approaches: interactional linguistics cross-cultural pragmatics; discourse studies (intersects with pragmatics); semantics (?information structure, Frame) (?dialogic/construction grammar -- probably not this project) The narrative structure models I've studied so far seem very disconnected from recent theory. The model we adopt has a direct impact on how narrative structures are annotated (categories, but more importantly process). I've started to read about pragmatics/semantics to pitch ideas for an updated model.Looking at how these models coded their data does not seem very useful to us; it's incompletely described, and it's not an example of good practices. I think a better alternative is to look into recent publications about best practices for linguistic annotation, like: Handbook of Linguistic Annotation (general reference; book) Hoek & Scholman 2017 (focuses on discourse; article) Best practices would impact the workflow, the labels used, and the description given in our writing. Learning about best practices can also be used to quality-check past annotations (& correct/re-do, or just learn from it for future projects). Episode boundaries are sensitive to some types of expressions/functions; distribution is different at +start of ep VS -start of ep. The forms populating the distribution are language-specific; so something like "nouns are overrepresented at the start of ep" is a falsified claim. That's true for some languages, and the opposite is true for others. What's comparable across languages is: that there are similar distribution patterns (pure stats) + that there's a shared set of "types of expressions/functions sensitive to ep boundary" + that it organizes around a binary (+- start of ep). Types of expressions/functions sensitive to EP boundary We can propose additions to the list of types of expressions/functions sensitive to ep boundary she presented. We can reframe it more clearly with a split between function & potential forms = semantics/pragmatics VS syntax/lexicon, roughly. (More speculative: maybe some elements ought to be removed from the inventory as spurious correlation that has to do with working memory.) Ji 2002 identifies these variables as salient indicators of episode boundaries. Meaning, when given the task to place episode boundaries, research participants highly agree in case of (+) conditions, and agree a lot less in case of (-) conditions. The study was conducted in just one language (English), but it builds an inventory of functions & form types, rather than language-specific forms. +- Marked sentence +- Discontinuity in time, space +- Discontinuity in theme, if it has an additional feature: +- New participant +- Anaphor ==(non-participant theme with no callback = adds little-to-no episode boundary salience, for example.) +- Major discontinuity (any type) I wonder why theme did not receive further, more precise split. Anaphor is significant beyond 'theme discontinuity'; most obviously 'referring expression (pron vs NP)'. Compare "linking construction". ('Marked sentence' + Anaphor -> information structure) linguaculture: "culture manifested through language use" (p.5) linguacultures vary within and between languages; the point of "linguaculture" is to make a small claim, connected to a community of practice speech acts: typology of speech acts from Edmondson & House 1981 p.107 they warn against proliferation of new types of speech act; better to identify subtypes than new types expression: "lexical items of various complexity" (p.73) tertium comparationis: "A common quality in two entities to be compared, which is the basis of the comparison." (p.260); nb different types of stable variables possible principle of comparability standard situation: "The notion of a standard situation involves participants’ rather fixed expectations and perceptions of social role. Role relations are transparent and predetermined, the requester has a right, the requestee an obligation, the degree of imposition involved in the request is low, as is the perceived degree of difficulty in realizing it. In a nutshell, the participants know where and who they are. Clearly, the distinction between a standard and a nonstandard situation is not clear cut." (p.76) language use in standard situation can be studied in one linguaculture, then compared with another/several they exclude study of language use in non-standard situations, and idiosyncratic uses ritual VS conventionalization, ritual frame, RFIE (ritual frame-indicating expression) ... ancillary methodology vs comparative methodology: ancillary methods are exploratory pilot studies comparative methods (in cross-cultural pragmatics) = compare use of expressions in standard situation in at least 2 linguacultures discourse gambit linking constructions (type of gambit): see p.144 + their source: https://benjamins.com/catalog/target.27.3.03hou types of talk Multidisciplinary Introduction to Discourse_chapter: Narrative in Everyday LifeScope of narrative Narrative and time Narrative point of view and plot structure beginning, middle, end setting: place + time + social context. (+ mental landscape) "complication", "initiating event", etc.: event that disrupts equilibrium of the ordinary "psychological responses and actions" "outcome" //Ok so some division with 3 units is established in multiple disciplines. I'm wondering to what extent we need something special called "narrative structure". is it superfluous? is it 90% generic semantics/discourse structure + 10% conventions for content & interpretation?// Building a narrative p.77 "The audience is a co-author of narrative form and meaning." Introduction Discourse & Cognition Discourse pragmatics Discourse, grammar and interaction Conversation analysis: An approach to the analysis of social interaction Discourse and culture Based on naturalistic data (from English-speaking white american families, so NB limitations) "narrators in conversational setting interactionally create narratives by recruiting discourse skills that are most readily available to them" //I find this paper insightful because it considers both language use & cognitive use (whereas eg story grammar focuses on cognitive representation, per the author). This captures the importance of interpretation in discourse structure.//Episode boundaries = Points where an episode starts Start of episode: Over-representation of NP //English-specific// New Macroproposition //More generalizable idea// This bit jumps out: "macropropositions do not set up an episode boundary, rather they set up a subunit within the master episode. They are considered part of the master episode since they maintain the thematic/topical continuity of it" Continuity vs discontinuity has a lot to do with how episodes connect, whether you go up or down in structure as story unfolds. Would be great to search for recent publications that follow up on this.Schiffrin 1981 (on tense/aspect): p.52 "Thus, finding no narratives told entirely in the HP, she concludes that it is not the HP per se which is a dramatic device in narrative, but the switch. The tendency for verbs in one tense to cluster together is given a functional, discourse-level explanation: maintenance of one tense groups events into one scene or episode, while switching separates events from one another." //The key idea is "switch" or "pair". What makes up the pair depends on multiple factors (temporal perspective adopted, TAMP system of the language, etc.), but it's always a pair.//Labov 1972: p.363: "Fully formed narrative may show the following: Abstract Orientation Complicating event Evaluation Result or resolution Coda" This publication adds a narrative unit, relative to Labov & Waletzky 1967 It has more definitions and explanations of terms see Defina & Johnstone 2015 pp.153-154 for mise en contexte of + terms from Labov 1972 Worth reading/thinking about more closely, the narrative units presented are heterogenous in a way that bothers me (plot units vs units giving explicit interpretation grid?). Need to return to this Mithun 2002 (on nominalization) p.58-61 Nominalized sentences for backgrounding information "The speaker steps out of the narrative or other account to offer side comments, background description, explanation, evaluation, or other supplementary commentary. The nominalization of independent clauses provides an important rhetorical device for adding texture to discourse, separating the main event line or sequential points in a discussion from side commentary." //Compare to nominalization + backgrounding particles in Wan, and particles 'and', 'already', converbs in Chuvash. Maybe read more about: backgrounding vs foregrounding. This is in the domain of information structure. Also NB it's the only category Nikitina presents without a pair for -Start of unit.//Tomlin 1987 p.455: Focus/foregrounding! p.457: "First, the critical theoretical linguistic notions, — paragraph, episode, and focus, — are weakly defined and generally resistant to empirical analysis. Second, and not independent of the first weakness, the practical identification of such notions in genuine text data depends on relativistic thematic notions of relevance and salience, which are similarly vague at the present moment (van Dijk and Kintsch 1983:171; but see also Tomlin 1984, 1985)" p.457-458: Comprehension strategies & production strategies don't have to be the same p.458 Macroproposition p.461 Proposition ... p.472: Shift in attention during discourse production p.475: "The primary drawback to the episode/paragraph approach lies in the dif ficulty of providing explicit and structure-independent means of identifying episodes and episode boundaries. In this study episodes are argued to be a function of attention allocation, and episode boundaries are identified and manipulated independently of text structure and without dependence on introspection. It may even suggest that in the end discourse units, like the paragraph, are more likely to be the artifacts of linguistic analysis than they are cognitive units utilized by speakers in discourse production" Need to return to this, very perceptive.Fox 1987 (NP/pron anaphora)
(chapter starts here: tomlin1987, p.157) p.157-158: distance, ambiguity, thematic continuity p.167-172: Pron vs NP, looks at some problem with just analyzing use in terms of linear distance + nuances of NP/pron distribution Need to return to thisVan Dijk 1981 ...Bakker 1993 Boundaries, Topics and the Structure of discourse Discontinuity of participants and events Perspectival discontinuity

item.description: Source:Compare with Trabasso & Nickels Narrative structure gets demoted in B&S...Language acquisition Cross-linguistic research; comparative linguisticsStoryboard elicitation (Frog, Where Are You?) Data collected from children. ? ADULTS (probably included too? Multiple language/cultures (English, Spanish, German, Hebrew, Turkish); monolingualThere are many studies based on eliciting retellings of the Frog story (1979). Some of them analyze narrative macrostructure. Most studies focus on microstructure, not macrostructure. Findings from this type of study are limited, because it's a single story and not designed to control for complexity or cultural appropriateness like MAIN. Frog story studies are often done on minority languages, and they represent a highly diverse set of languages/cultures. For now, I focused on collecting macrostructure terms. I did not find definitions, everything is paraphrased/deduced.There are a lot more terms: ?? maybe for microstructure and micro-macro interface in part IV pp.389-59X for lg-specific categories in part III pp. XXX-XXX. For the upcoming project, a closer look at terms (+ definition + coding) from these chapters might be useful: pp.389-39X: Form-Function Relations in the Development of Narrative pp.393-45X: Temporal Relations in Narrative: Simultaneity Macrostructure seems to get little use in the analysis; microstructure (language-specific forms) get most of the attention. This is a reconstruction! The coding schema is described in depth in Chapter I-B (pp.25-28). I checked App II: Glossing & Transcription in case it might provide more details about coding schema; it doesn't but NB! p.660 definition of clause as unit of transcription. The description is incomplete. More can be reconstructed by looking through analytical chapters (I started but then discontinued this task); see TERMS Much of the coding is not deployed in the analysis (p.27), which makes it impossible to fully reconstruct. Transcription is divided into clauses.All clauses are labelled. Some words (mostly verbs) are labelled when they fit certain categories.Coding was not made through a standard method used in all languages.   Rather, it was split into (1) analyzing forms = lg-specific, (2) analyzing functions = applicable across languages, hence lg-neutral.pp.85-106: categories from Trabasso & Nickels 1992 (-> Trabasso et al 1989, Stein & Glenn 1979) are used to model the stimulus story "Frog where are you", and for the coding schema for narrations of "Frog where are you" collected before B&S 1994NB these sources have a variable level of engagement with Berman & Slobin; what they have in common is the method.Works based on the same method, macrostructure: Rungrojsuwan 2019 Thai / Monolingual research Shunhua-Tianlong2023 Mandarin Chinese / Monolingual research Works based on the same method, microstructure Klamer Moro 2020 Alorese, Teiwa (two languages of indonesia) / Monolingual research Brown 2004 Tzeltal / Monolingual research Bennett Kastor 2002 Irish + English bilinguals / Multilingual research, microstructure Bavin 2000 WarlpiriTable of studies using Frog story on languages of Africa OverallConvergence relative to source: Purpose: lang acq Method: same method has been used abundantly before & afterDivergence relative to source: Purpose: lang descriptionTheir narrative model has broad applicability largely through vague, undefined terms. This avoids the problem of having a precise model that only fits certain languages/cultures. But it's very limited in terms of studying differences in macrostructure. item.title: GagarinaEtAl2019_Notes
item.description: This study had monolingual adults as participants; speakers of German, Swedish, and Russian. It sets a benchmark for studies with children. p.192-193: Models of narrative complexity developed in the 70s-80s. Narrative = setting + one or more episodes. Episode = initiating event + internal response + internal plan + attempt + direct consequence + reaction. An episode might not have all of these elements; episodes are more or less complex depending on the number of elements present. Stein & Glenn's 1979 story grammar model is one of those models. It is still used in recent narrative research. p. 193: MAIN builds on these prior models. The model developed involves complete unites (episodes) that have 5 components. 2 of them (initiation, and reaction; internal states of the protagonist) frame the 3 components that form the core content of the episode: Goal, Attempt, Outcome. The narrative also needs a statement setting (time & place) at the start. Research with MAIN can be qualitative or quantitative (p.193-194), and involves telling stories based on a set of images. The set was designed for broad cross-cultural appropriateness. p.204: Participants had similar production regardless of language groups. -> "This is good evidence for the pictorial stimuli being cross-linguistically and cross-culturally robust, at least for three groups of monolingual adults (all Europeans, and all literate)" Imo it doesn't demonstrate appropriateness beyond Western cultures and languages. But then again, a lot of narrative research seems developed for use in evaluating students, educational needs & language impairment; this creates a bias towards tools that are "cross-cultural" but only really need to be relevant for WEIRD populations, by which I mean industrialized/rich moreso than Western. p.204-205: "story complexity was not found to differ significantly, neither between languages nor between stories (Baby Goats vs. Baby Birds). This finding suggests that story complexity (i.e. the qualitative evaluation of macrostructure) may be of a more universal nature than story structure." Complexity here was a matter of number of episodes with full Goal-Action-Outcome sequences. p.205-206: Goals are not always explicitly included in narratives of adult -- this creates a problem for the theory, because goals are seen as central to narratives, and their omission can't be attributed to the storytellers' low skills. The authors resolve this by formulating alternatives to GAO. 1) IAO sequence (internal state as initiating event, attempt, outcome). 'Internal states' were included more frequently than Goals, and they can be the starting point of an episode. 2) EAO sequence (initiating event, attempt, outcome)

item.title: NOTES_Cultural variation
NOTES_Wider background
item.description: This summary is just based on Tappe & Hara 2013, so very brief. Three phases of narrative research (I suspect this just covers Anglo academia; lacks engagement with French, Russian,… predecessors): 70-80s: taxonomy of narrative elements, 'story grammar' and 'story schema'. Narratives that adhere to so-called canonical structure lead to "greater ease of processing, better understanding and better recall" than those with non-canonical structure. 70-80: flexible use and complexity of narrative text structures. This phase studied the use of structures by different types of readers, and found developmental differences across groups of school-age readers. 80-'current' (as of 2013): investigating whether story structure (as understood in phase 1 and 2) can be taught to improve reading comprehension. Much of this research has been monolingual. Multilingual narrative research seems to begin in the 2010s (may be incorrect; need to find more articles first). Narrative research falls under multiple disciplines: social sciences and humanities in general = discourse studies; may not engage much with macrostructure??. Eg Labovian applied linguistics = research on development of narrative skills for diagnostic use. Eg MAIN linguistics = research on development of narrative skills to study language acquisition. Eg Frog story Story grammar models (esp Stein & Glenn) are influential in all these disciplines. Articles: doing-narrative-research2013intro = social sciences gimenez 2010 narrative analysis in linguistic research = narrative networks, sociolinguistics These sources don't discuss macrostructure. Lang2003 (ch12 of Narrative Intelligence): pp.199-200 on background; todo split chapter and upload Todo: find other sources of this type, esp background with a focus on story grammar, macrostructure
